subtitle: Hello, I'm Jeffrey Mishlove. There's an
irony, even to me saying something as
simple as, "I am Jeffrey Mishlove." I
remember, oh gosh, 15 years ago when I was
a very young man I was keeping a diary
on audio tape. I had a big tape recorder
and I would make audio diaries. I may
still have them around somewhere. I
remember very distinctly in one of
these I made a point to say, "I am not
Jeffrey Mishlove. No, I'm a spiritual
being. Jeffrey Mishlove is just a label
somebody slapped on me." It's true,
we are not our name. Our name is only a
label. I should have introduced myself by
saying, "Hello, my label is Jeffrey
Mishlove. That's my handle." But who I am,
who I am is something very different. Who
you are, you are far, far more than your
name. And I see I got into the habit,
how many now, over a hundred of these
interviews, in fact there are like
over 700 uploaded now on the channel
and in how many of them do I say, "I am
Jeffrey Mishlove"? Well, I got news for you.
I'm not. It was a name given to me by my
parents at the time of my birth and it's
been convenient. It's a good thing I
suppose to have a name but it's not
really who I am.
Funny thing about that. Well, I thought I
would talk a little bit today
about the idea of cultivation,
cultivating yourself and working on
yourself, or another phrase I often use
is inner work. If you were to go to the
original Thinking Allowed website, thinking
allowed dot com, where videotapes are being
sold from the original series that ran
from 1986 to 2002 - that website's run by
my partner Arthur Block - you would see
that we have a whole series of
video tapes called Inner Work, where I
would do a half hour interview with a
guest, which was broadcast at the time we
were out on the satellite over public TV
stations all across North America.
Then we would do an extra hour.
Sometimes it would just be an additional
interview, but often the extra hour
focused on ways in which people can work
on themselves, become better human beings,
become the best versions of themselves
so to speak. Well, there's a paradox
when it comes to inner work. It kind
of goes like this. You're perfectly fine
just the way you are. You don't need to
change a thing. That's an important
realization for people because many
of us have issues of low self-esteem, at
least partial low self-esteem in
different areas of our life where we
really feel we're not good enough.
What we need to do is to let go of that
feeling because it's just not true.
Wherever you are at this point in
time is fine for you, unless you're in
absolute agony or something and need to
dramatically, drastically change your
situation, chances are that you'll be
just fine as you are for the rest of
your life.
Yet, on the other hand, of course you
want to be better, you want to work, you
want to improve, you want to have a sense of
progress through your life. It's not
necessary. It's not essential. You can
stay the way you are. The great irony
is if you just accept yourself, if you
just stay the way you are, you'll find
that you're going to change anyway. In fact,
by adopting an attitude of, "I'm fine. I'm
okay. The way I am right now will suit me
very well for the rest of my life," that's
an attitude that actually opens you up
to the possibility of change in many
different directions. But, it's not quite
the same as saying, "I've got a particular
issue I want to work on, I want to get
better on." Of course we can do that.
And now what I'd like to bring up as an
example from my own life, in fact I'm
going to bring up two examples. Let's
start with the first one, karaoke.
It's been a few days since I shared with
you that tape of me singing karaoke. I
recorded it on my iPhone and I released
it knowing that it wasn't as good as I
could be. You see, in years past I was
really into karaoke. I went several times
a week and I even performed. I went to a
Jewish center where they had elderly
people who would gather for lunch once a
month and I would perform for them as
a way of free entertainment for them. I
had a partner at the time who had been a
professional singer so it kind of upped the
level of the performance considerably.
But I worked at those. I practiced. I
know that back then, 7, 8 years
ago, maybe 9 or 10 years ago, I was
much better than I am now, and which is
why I noted in the introduction to that
video I know I'm rusty. I know that I
didn't hit
all of the notes. I didn't get all of the words.
My rhythm wasn't as good as it could be
and my articulation could have been much
better. So, it's an example of a skill
that I had, that I practiced and worked
at that I've lost some of, and I
think I can get it back. I think what
I'd like to do is to do exactly that
but I know I need to work at. It's not
going to happen automatically. It's
not hard work because I like to sing and
so it'll be fine. In the
future, I'm going to make some additional
videos of myself singing karaoke.
I'm going to post them. The
feedback is quite interesting because a
few of you pointed out quite correctly:
"Don't quit your day job to become a
singer." And other people said, "Well, I
listened to about as much of it as I could
stand." And I totally get that because
that video I released was fun for
me and some of you said, "Wow. I really
like it. Let's have more of that. I love
karaoke." Well, when you go to listen to
karaoke at a club or a bar or any place
where they have karaoke, you're going
to hear lots of people singing off-key.
That's part of the fun of it, I guess.
It's much better when people do sing on
key. Many people said, "Please, let's
have more of that. It shows you, how human
you are." I'd like to show you how human I
am but I'd also like to get better.
My thinking is this: I'm going to do this
and I'm going to post those videos
occasionally, not a lot, showing that
I actually am making progress in my
singing ability. I hope that you take
it as an inspiration to find something
in your life that you feel comfortable
that you can
work on, that you want to work on, that
you're not going to put yourself through
some sort of agony to do it. You have
that opportunity to get better at
something along with me. Now, there's no
guarantee I'll get better. I may be
too old. I may be too rusty. I may be not
sufficiently motivated or simply lack
sufficient talent to get any better than
I was.
That's a risk. I'll take that risk.
We'll see what happens.
It's an opportunity for you to pick
some area that you really want to work
on and take a little risk to see if you
can get better at some one thing. Now,
there's something else I need to
work on too and I'm going to be very frank
with you about this because when I
viewed that video of me standing up and
singing like that, I noticed, "Hey, wait,
look at him, he's got a potbelly." I mostly
don't show it. You'll notice when I make these videos
it's from the nipple side up, so to speak because I'd
rather not reveal how chubby I've
become. But, it's something I have to work
on. I really know I do. I'm
carrying a good ten pounds more weight at
this moment than I had a few months ago.
I've jumped up about 10 pounds and it
happened at a time when we had a lot of
house guests and we were having quite a
few large meals and I really got into
the deserts. It took me about 30
days or so and I put on 10 pounds and
I've been struggling to take it off.
The truth is I should take off about
30. But I'm saying that now, I'm being
public about it now because I want you
to know it's something I'm working on.
I want to be here in front of this
camera just like this. I don't know
when it'll be, I'm not putting any
pressure on myself,
I'm okay with myself at my present weight,
but you know what I'm going to take that
weight off and I'm going to announce it.
At some point I'm going to say on one of
these "In Presence" monologues, "Yes, I've
lost that 10 pounds and now I'm going
for the next 10." My intention in
doing that and being so public about it
is to be a bit of an inspiration for you,
a bit of a role model in that sense, and
to create a space, an opportunity for
those of you who wish to take me up on
it, pick something else like that for
yourself, something you would like to work on,
two things. We'll both get better at
the same time. How about that? Are you
willing to do that? That's my challenge
to you. I'll leave you with that
thought. What would you like to pick to
work on? Thank you for being with me.
